awd_titl_txt: Conference on Mathematical Sciences Challenges in Quantum Information
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports participation in a conference on mathematical sciences challenges in quantum information science, held 12-13 February 2015 in Arlington, Virginia.  The field of quantum information (QI) explores the theoretical, experimental, and technological areas covering the use and implications of quantum mechanics for communication and computation purposes.  While conceptually all of the diverse aspects that QI encompasses arise from the seemingly simple appreciation of information as a physical resource, its consequences have the potential to revolutionize computation, communication, and ideas about complexity. In particular, QI promises exponentially more efficient quantum algorithms for solving hard combinatorial problems and for simulating the behavior of complex quantum systems, along with unprecedented opportunities for secure communication and new perspectives to tackle a range of problems in physics, biology, applied mathematics, engineering, and computer sciences. As a result, QI is currently a thriving and naturally interdisciplinary research area, and one of critical strategic relevance to 21st century's science and technology. 

As the QI field is entering a new stage of maturity, further progress is increasingly relying on the use of diverse advanced mathematical techniques. In turn, new areas of mathematics are being identified, which offer the potential for major future advances in the field. This award supports a one-and-a-half-day conference that brings together leading researchers working across a broad spectrum of problems in QI theory, with the goals of (i) highlighting the centrality and importance of mathematical tools; and (ii) assessing outstanding mathematical challenges and formulating a vision for the future. A distinguished group of speakers will highlight the latest research developments and open problems in topics, including quantum channels and quantum error correction theory, quantum marginals, random quantum states and dynamics, many-body quantum systems, and quantum control. Panel discussions and breakout sessions are intended to identify new promising directions for investigations. The expected broad impacts of the proposed conference are twofold. On the one hand, the conference facilitates collaborative exploration between academic and federal agency scientists of the short- to mid-term mathematical challenges in advancing the field of QI -- with a written report being anticipated as an output of the conference. On the other hand, the conference serves as a vehicle to enlist mathematically-oriented scientists to bring their ideas to bear on accessible fundamental problems in QI, and to educate the next generation of scientists working in this very important field.

por.por_cntn:
The field of Quantum Information (QI) explores the theoretical, experimental and technological areas covering the use and implications of quantum mechanics for communication and computation purpose.  While conceptually all of the diverse aspects that QI encompasses stem from the seemingly simple appreciation of information as a physical resource, its consequences have the potential to revolutionize computation, communication, and complexity as we have known them thus far.  In particular, QI promises exponentially more efficient quantum algorithms for solving hard combinatorial problems and for simulating the behavior of complex quantum systems, along with unprecedented opportunities for secure communication and new perspectives to tackle a range of problems in physics, chemistry, biology, applied mathematics, engineering and computer sciences. As a result, QI is currently one of the most thriving and naturally interdisciplinary research areas, and one of critical strategic relevance to 21st century's science and technology.

As a worldwide effort is underway to build practical QI processing devices, and as the QI field is entering a new stage of maturity, further progress is increasingly relying on the use of advanced and diverse mathematical techniques. In turn, new areas of mathematics are being identified, that offer the potential for major future advances in the field. The Conference on Mathematical Sciences Challenges in Quantum Information, organized by the principal investigator, Professor Lorenza Viola (Dartmouth College), with the help of colleague Professor Aram Harrow (MIT), was held in Arlington, VA, on February 12-13, 2015, in response to this need. The goal was multi-fold: on the one hand, highlighting the centrality of mathematical tools in the field, assessing outstanding QI challenges and identifying emerging frontiers; on the other hand, soliciting input from stakeholders about perceived priorities and a vision for the future. The conference included 10 invited presentations by leading experts in the field, along with panel discussions and break-out sessions, and was attended by a total of about 40 people, including several representatives from US funding agencies and the government. 

The Conference has played an instrumental role in helping identifying especially important areas of investigation where a wide range of mathematical challenges exist and/or will continue to emerge. These may be broadly organized around the four topics of

(i) Quantum algorithms;

(ii) Quantum simulation;

(iii) Quantum control, error correction and fault-­tolerance;

(iv) Entanglement and quantum correlations.

Although the specifics vary, one common theme is that such topics require expertise that cuts across traditional disciplinary boundaries, and that combines core areas of quantum and classical information theory, quantum physics, and applied mathematics with state-­of-­the-­art, specialized mathematical techniques. The Conference has also served to highlight how the intrinsically cross-­disciplinary nature of the QI field is both an opportunity and a source of structural challenges for QI research in the US, and has helped identifying some key programmatic recommendations. In particular, a major focal point has been identified in the importance of maintaining stable support for QI research, with adequate emphasis on curiosity-­driven investigations and with more flexible funding mechanisms.
